body:
It seems to boil down to occasional failures when downloading packages
On Mac:
```
gyp WARN install got an error, rolling back install
gyp ERR! configure error 
gyp ERR! stack Error: This is most likely not a problem with node-gyp or the package itself and
gyp ERR! stack is related to network connectivity. In most cases you are behind a proxy or have bad 
gyp ERR! stack network settings.
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.<anonymous> (/Users/kbuilder/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/install.js:193:21)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.emit (events.js:211:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.onRequestError (/Users/kbuilder/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/request/request.js:878:8)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:211:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at TLSSocket.socketErrorListener (_http_client.js:387:9)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at TLSSocket.emit (events.js:211:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitErrorNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:64:8)
gyp ERR! System Darwin 15.6.0
gyp ERR! command "/Users/kbuilder/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/bin/node" "/Users/kbuilder/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "configure" "--fallback-to-build" "--library=static_library" "--module=/Volumes/BuildData/tmpfs/src/github/grpc/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core/src/node/extension_binary/node-v57-darwin-x64-unknown/grpc_node.node" "--module_name=grpc_node" "--module_path=/Volumes/BuildData/tmpfs/src/github/grpc/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core/src/node/extension_binary/node-v57-darwin-x64-unknown"
gyp ERR! cwd /Volumes/BuildData/tmpfs/src/github/grpc/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core
```

On Linux:
```
gyp WARN install got an error, rolling back install
gyp ERR! configure error 
gyp ERR! stack Error: 522 response downloading https://nodejs.org/dist/v8.9.4/node-v8.9.4-headers.tar.gz
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.<anonymous> (/root/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/install.js:210:14)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:121:20)
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.emit (events.js:211:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.onRequestResponse (/root/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/request/request.js:1068:10)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:211:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at HTTPParser.parserOnIncomingClient (_http_client.js:551:21)
gyp ERR! stack     at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete (_http_common.js:116:23)
gyp ERR! stack     at TLSSocket.socketOnData (_http_client.js:440:20)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
gyp ERR! System Linux 4.4.0-83-generic
gyp ERR! command "/root/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/bin/node" "/root/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "configure" "--fallback-to-build" "--library=static_library" "--module=/var/local/git/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core/src/node/extension_binary/node-v57-linux-x64-glibc/grpc_node.node" "--module_name=grpc_node" "--module_path=/var/local/git/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core/src/node/extension_binary/node-v57-linux-x64-glibc"
gyp ERR! cwd /var/local/git/grpc-node/packages/grpc-native-core
gyp ERR! node -v v8.9.4
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v3.6.2
gyp ERR! not ok 
```
@murgatroid99 , what can we do to increase build robustness?

This looks like a network failure when downloading external resources that are required for the tests. There is only so much we can do about failures like that. And it's difficult to programmatically distinguish between that and a compilation failure, so I don't know if we want to just blindly retry.

I understand this issue is pain to deal with, but currently the flakiness is a bit too high and we should figure out something. 
Is there a way we can isolate the "prepare" commands (that download and install the prerequisites) from the actual build of our code and only retry the first group?

Still one of our top flakes:
Recent failures:
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=85ef8bbf-abf1-44e5-8eb1-dd907be6b3f6
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=20ac6419-cf0e-4ed2-8349-18f58d6469ec
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=d3010f84-dc0e-4781-83bf-30f0e8257a9e
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=e2477c01-8b15-4d7a-9fab-d80ec2dfa0d7

Still seeing this (and still on the list of our top few flakes).
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?tab=Build+Log&id=f91bec72-924f-4657-a3c2-088f398ccb11

We really ought to fix this somehow, we can't have this failing forever.

@matt-kwong , do you have any ideas how we could reduce the flakiness rate?

This is still happening:
https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/6b46c30a-11f1-452f-bd6d-e31fe2eddb1b/targets/github%2Fgrpc%2Fgrpc-node_linux_dbg_native/tests
https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/6b46c30a-11f1-452f-bd6d-e31fe2eddb1b/targets/github%2Fgrpc%2Fgrpc-node_linux_dbg_native/tests
```
> @grpc/grpc-js@0.1.0 prepare /var/local/git/grpc-node/packages/grpc-js-core
> npm run compile
> @grpc/grpc-js@0.1.0 compile /var/local/git/grpc-node/packages/grpc-js-core
> tsc -p .
npm ERR! Unexpected end of input while parsing '{"versions":{"1.0.0":{"name":"semver","v'
npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /tmp/npm-cache/_logs/2018-05-22T06_42_13_797Z-debug.log
[06:42:13] 'protobuf.install' errored after 1.43 min
[06:42:13] Error: Command failed: npm install --unsafe-perm
    at /var/local/git/grpc-node/node_modules/execa/index.js:236:11
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:438:9)
npm notice created a lockfile as package-lock.json. You should commit this file.
added 179 packages from 110 contributors in 88.666s
[06:42:16] Finished 'js.core.install' after 1.48 min
Command exited with non-zero status 1
```
The linked PR will hopefully decrease the frequency of this failure. Until we know what the impact of that PR is I am going to downgrade this to a P2.
